newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Fuel Oil - Rises as new buying demand emerges.
newsitem.headline: Asia Fuel Oil - Rises as new buying demand emerges.

text.p: The Singapore high sulphur fuel oil prices edged higher on Monday amid fresh buying demand as well as crude gains, traders said.
After four cargoes exchanged hands last week, traders said they expected increased interest this week.
A 180-cst cargo for July 19-23 lifting was traded at $101.50 per tonne, compared with Friday's trading level at $100.00 and $101.00 per tonne.
Two related Singapore traders bought three cargoes last week and the market was expecting continued demand from them.
One of the two traders said the company is looking to cover some of its short positions.
"It looks like the local trader is pretty keen in buying. But we have to wait for a few days to see if his buying will continue," said one trader.

Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp (CPC) said on Monday it had bought through tender at least one 38,000-tonne cargo of 0.5-percent sulphur fuel oil for delivery between July 21 and August 15.
CPC bought the low-pour fuel oil at above $127 per tonne on a cost-and-freight Kaohsiung basis, a CPC official said.
In its last purchase, CPC bought two 38,000-tonne cargoes of of low-sulphur fuel oil, with the low-pour cargo at $129 per tonne and the high-pour cargo at $123, for July deliveries.
A company source said CPC might not seek further fuel oil imports in the near term.
The swaps market inched up also over fresh buying demand from the physical market.
July swaps were at $99.25/$100.00 against Friday's $98.00/$99.00 and August swaps were at $98.25/$99.00 against $97.75/$98.50.
Late on Monday, no transaction was reported on SIMEX fuel
oil futures contract, with July contract bid/offered at
MTH FOB SIN BUY/SELL PREV BUY/SELL
AUG FUEL OIL SWAPS 98.25/99.00 97.75/98.50
*Dollars per barrel
-- Singapore newsroom (+65-870 3571)
